awd_titl_txt: TiO2 Photocatalysis: The coupling of electrons, plasmons, polarons, and molecules by ultrafast photoemission spectroscopy and theory
awd_abstract_narration:
Titanium dioxide (Ti02) is a model system for solar energy capture and transfer to drive chemical processes.  The material has the ability to absorb ultraviolet (UV) light and use it to assist in, or catalyze, the decomposition of water (H2O) to hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) gases, which can be stored and later combined to produce energy on demand.  The material can also catalyze the reduction of carbon dioxide (CO2), a greenhouse gas that is the final product of burning fossil fuels, and transform this environmentally harmful gas into useful hydrocarbons for the chemical industry. Dr. Petek is engaged in fundamental studies of how this material absorbs UV light to create electron-hole pairs and how these electrons and holes are transported through the material and used to effect chemical change for sustainable solar energy conversion. The fast speeds of these reactions are measured in femtoseconds (1 femtosecond equals 0.000000000000001 second), and are studied by ultrafast laser spectroscopy.  Dr. Petek and his collaborator, Dr. Zhao, combine advanced ultrafast laser spectroscopy experiments with theoretical calculations to understand these photo-catalytic events.  In addition to the broader impacts of the research to contribute to the development of clean and efficient solar energy capture, there are substantial educational benefits for the students involved in the project. The collaborative arrangement that Dr. Petek has established with Dr. Zhao at the University of Science and Technology China and her co-worker Dr. Min Feng at Wuhan University provides excellent opportunities for students from the University of Pittsburgh to work in the Chinese laboratories, as well as for Chinese students to serve as summer interns in Dr.  Petek's laboratory.  To broaden student participation in research, Dr. Petek uses the Pittsburgh Quantum Initiative to recruit talented undergraduate students into research assistantships.  He is an ardent promotor of photocatalytic research, working to organize of international symposia on the topic as well as serving in the role of Editor-in-Chief of the journal Progress in Surface Science. 

With funding from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Dr. Petek and Dr. Zhao study the electron spectroscopy and dynamics related to photocatalytic processes by means of time-resolved two-photon photoemission (TR-2PP) experiments and advanced electronic structure theory.  The 2PP spectra and time resolved measurements reveal the polaronic character of electrons introduced into the conduction band of TiO2, the interaction of chemisorbed molecules with the polarons, and the unoccupied resonances of chemisorbed molecules such as CO2.  Dr. Petek conducts TR-2PP experiments on noble metal decorated TiO2 surfaces to reveal the mechanisms of plasmonically enhanced photocatalysis. In collaboration, Dr. Zhao performs electronic structure calculations to identify the electron and hole acceptor states, potentially involved in photocatalysis, for molecules adsorbed on TiO2 surface. In addition, nonadiabatic molecular dynamics calculations are used to describe the interfacial charge transfer dynamics and carrier energy relaxation rates for chemisorbed molecular overlayers at finite temperatures. The research has broader impacts as it brings together experimentalists and theorists from the University of Pittsburgh and University of Science and Technology of China (USTC) to work on the fundamental aspects of sustainable solar energy conversion via TiO2 photocatalysis. In addition to the broader impacts of the research, there are substantial educational benefits for students involved in the established collaborative project between the USTC and Wuhan University with the University of Pittsburgh, which provides opportunities for undergraduate and graduate student international exchange. To broaden student participation in research, Dr. Petek uses the Pittsburgh Quantum Initiative to recruit talented undergraduate students into research assistantships.  He is an ardent promotor of photocatalytic research, working to organize of international symposia on the topic as well as serving in the role of Editor-in-Chief of the journal Progress in Surface Science

por.por_cntn:
Metal oxides are a technologically important class of materials in applications including catalysis, magnetism, sensors, superconductors, ceramics, optical materials, etc. Many of their applications involve the interaction of electromagnetic fields with their charge or spin degrees of freedom. The dynamical properties of metal oxides, where the charge, spin, and lattice degrees of freedom interact to define novel properties, are poorly known, because methods to probe their interactions are difficult to implement. We explored the spectroscopy and dynamics of rutile TiO2(110) single crystal samples. TiO2 is a known photocatalyst, and serves as a model for other metal oxide materials, because it is possible to prepare atomically defined single crystal samples, and probe their optical and electronic properties under well defined conditions. A common defect that occurs in metal oxides is the formation of oxygen atom vacancy defects. Such defects form under reducing conditions, such as heating the sample, or sputtering of surfaces by energetic ions. Removing oxygen atoms from TiO2 leaves excess electrons that occupy a defect energy band below the conduction band minimum. This defect band changes the color of TiO2 from clear, to black, because its stoichiometric form absorbs only in the ultraviolet, but in the reduced form the defect electrons absorb in the infrared-visible range of the optical spectrum.

            We have investigated the electronic structure and electron dynamics in reduced TiO2 by femtosecond (fs; 10-15 s time scale) nonlinear time resolved photoemission electron spectroscopy and many-body theory. Moreover, we performed similar measurements on gold nanoparticle decorated TiO2 surfaces, where the collective response of the gold free electron plasma greatly enhances the interaction with light, and transfers electrons or excites them in TiO2 substrate. By multiphoton photoemission spectroscopy of reduced TiO2, we could identify several defect related electronic states at 1.4-5 eV above the Fermi level, which most likely correspond to excitation of electrons from the occupied to unoccupied defect states. Having identified new electronic transitions, we could perform interferometric three and four photon photoemission experiments, where we excite the photoemission signal by identical pump and probe pulses separated by well-defined time delay that is scanned. These measurements were performed with <20 fs time resolution. Surprisingly, we found that the excitation creates a quantum mechanical superposition state of the ground and excited states, which persists on tens of femtosecond time scale. Moreover, we found that the excited state population decays on a similar time scale. This is surprising, because pervious measurements on TiO2 suggested that optically generated excitations decay much faster than the excitation pulse. In the case of gold nanoparticle decorated TiO2 surfaces we found that excitation of gold clusters generates higher energy electrons than was previously predicted by theory, which may be responsible for an enhanced photocatalytic activity.

            The many-body theory calculations concerned the interactions of electrons with the crystalline lattice and hole excitations in TiO2. The electron phonon interaction has familiar manifestations such as the temperature dependent resistivity of solid-state materials. We have found that the electronic states of TiO2 shift in temperature in a different manner than those of metals, which has been referred to in the literature as an anomalous electron-phonon interaction. We developed a theoretical understanding of transition metal oxides that explains the anomaly in terms of the frontier electron orbitals of metal atoms that interact with their proximate neighboring atoms. The familiar behavior of metals is a property of their s and p symmetry frontier orbitals. Transition metal oxides, however, have d-symmetry orbitals which respond differently to octahedrally distributed oxygen atoms, than would more familiar s and p-electron metals. Thus, the anomaly of the metal oxide behavior is due to their orbitals interacting with the neighboring atoms with a specific symmetry. In other words, their behavior is not anomalous, but rather, it reflects a different electronic character of such materials.

            In other work, we investigated the excitonic form of electronic excitation in anatase polymorph of TiO2. Exciting an electron from a valance band of a metal oxide generates an electron-hole pair. A hole is the charge distribution that remains after an electron is optically excited to a higher electronic state. It interacts with the promoted electron through the Coulomb interaction to form a quasiparticle named exciton. Thus, excitons represent excited states where the photon energy is captured as an excited electron hole pair. The stored photon energy within an exciton can induce subsequent chemical reactions, and thus characterizing excitons and their dynamics is important for the subsequent photocatalysis,  which they may cause. We performed many-body theory calculations to describe how direct excitons with same electron and hole crystal momenta, which have a large optical cross section, decay in energy into indirect excitons, where the electron and hole have different momenta. The theory shows that excitons have additional relaxation pathways for energy relaxation as compared with the uncorrelated electrons and holes.
